forum.title: The definition of juggling?
forum.content: For the moment that sounds pretty good. Though all the definitions I've went through in the past years have sounded great at first, and then of course they start to fall apart later on.

posts.content: For the moment that sounds pretty good. Though all the definitions I've went through in the past years have sounded great at first, and then of course they start to fall apart later on.
But then come the question, what if I, as a spectator sees object manipulation and determine that as juggling, which can sometimes be the case, does that then become juggling?
In a similar idea: What does juggling do that no other form can do? And if Object Manipulation is NOT juggling, why do we use it in the definition of juggling?

I have a feeling that the use of Object Manipulation comes from trying to escape the stereotypical context(clowns, circus, streetperforming etc), format(act, entertainment etc), aesthetics(spandex, glitter, vest, bowtie, flash etc) of juggling. The status of juggling is extremely low and that can bring difficulties.
To me, personally, juggling is the visual performance art of skilful object manipulation.

The attempt to demand that skill or risk is present for object manipulation to be juggling is hard to defend. In terms of the history and culture of juggling I would agree with you, though. It was around 1890 that Cinquevalli carved this distinction into the definition of juggling, separating it from magic, conjuring and prestidigitation which were common terms at the time. He insisted that juggling was pure skill, and that the skill was achieved by practice. Before that time, it was not so clear what the methods of achieving juggling were.
This being said, if one compares juggling to music, i think it was John Cage that stated that the silence between the sounds in music is also music. The same could be argued about juggling, that the moments "inbetween" the juggling, is also juggling.

I think that the moments in between performing (juggling) are also performing.
Why is it hard to defend the requirement of risk & skill?
Or did I miss that the differentiation was already made, as in (object manipulation)=(juggling (craft)) and the definition of art used is hence (to perform a craft with the intent to do so)?
To Julius, I think you have a good point there.
That is a common idea, right?
I'm personally partial to the definition you and Erik stated, object manipulation with the intent to manipulate--that currently feels good to me. Who knows if it will last!
Julius, If juggling is separated into art and craft, then Bernardo's definition goes for the art side of things. How would you define the craft of juggling, bearing this in mind?

I guess I'd go with object manipulation, which for me is the whole of ball/club/ring juggling, poi spinning, diabolo, devilstick,...
"Playing with any juggling instrument".
[Site note: As I type this, the preview is showing my points as being numbered 1. and 1. Be assured, I typed 1. and 2. , and did not indent the second one. I wonder what will actually be posted.]
Bernardo
Juggling is everything included the Juggling
But for juggling as an art form? Nope! Every juggler decides for themselves what is and isn't juggling, and usually that comes down to "what do I enjoy to do today?"
Bomb dropped.

That is a good one. Says something about context (found throughout etc) but not so much about content (includes objects in its choreography). In terms of content, would this be "choreography with objects"?
My own definition: Juggling - risk, skill and success.

forum.title: What was the significance of the peapot juggling series?
Clubs vs. Pins?
forum.content: Nope. Just can’t do it.

posts.content: https://ballsandjokes.com/2017/03/29/how-many-pins-can-you-juggle/
Nope. Just can’t do it.
Is there any historical precedent for calling them pins?

In Dutch they are called “kegels” which translates to pins, but the bowling association is not very strong, luckily. However, even older jugglers, or jugglers who have no connection to the scene, call them differently. This is looked down upon, those jugglers are outsiders because they use the “wrong” term. It’s weird.
On a historical note, I did some research on the history of bowling and possible connections to juggling. I could not find any, but I only spent a few days online, gathering what I could from there.

Nope. They were clubs right from the start. The only connection was later, when jugglers used plastic toy bowling pins to make juggling clubs. However, to do this, they had to greatly alter the shape of the bowling pin, cutting off it’s top. The following meme shares my feeling about the matter, in general.
I agree with Erik that it really doesn’t matter to the audience for the most part, but I personally don’t like supporting the idea that jugglers used bowling pins. When audience members pick up one of my clubs, they often will comment that they thought that they were much heavier, which then occasionally turns in to comments along the line of “Well that’s not nearly as hard as I thought.” I understand this to a point, because if I saw someone running backcrosses with five real bowling pins, I’d be mighty impressed. I just feel that supporting the common notion that jugglers use bowling pins has several negative side effects and no positive ones. In fact, I go out of my way in my show to explain that what I’m about to juggle are not bowling pins or some kind of small bat, but that they are juggling clubs, made specifically for juggling.
Just my personal thoughts on the subject.
Really interesting David. Thanks for your input.

Erik, I agree. I don’t see where the issue is. I’m in favor of communication that is democratic. In my opinion, the people have spoke, and they like “pin”. It doesn’t change the function of the object or even how we would talk about it if we called them clubs. For all I care they should just be Labeled props a-z

Here are some more thoughts on the issue. I want juggling to be taken seriously as an art form, hobby, athletic endeavor, and everything in between. As a result, there are certain notions about juggling that I want to dispel, or at the very least, not support. Jugglers using bowling pins and all being clowns are the top two things on that list. Secondly, being a juggling historian and museum curator, especially one that specializes in the history props, I feel that taking just a short opportunity here and there in my show to educate the audience, even while making them laugh, about juggling history is worth the effort. I may be the only professional juggler many of them ever see in person, so I want to be a good ambassador of juggling while I have the opportunity. If the audience can spend an hour being entertained and can come out also knowing a little more about juggling than they did when they got there, then I say that’s a good thing. That’s why I go out of my way, ever so briefly, to explain to my audience what juggling clubs are.

It seems as if it is often forgotten that words are only representations for actual concepts of reality. The word “club” and the object club, are not the same things. The word club only functions as a representative for the item, club, when spoken of.

I guess the question is: what should we call them. If the general public calls them pins why do we persist in calling them clubs?
Also I disagree that people don’t know what they are. People know the difference between a juggling pin and a bowling pin. If you showed someone a club and asked them what it was for, they’d say juggling and if you showed them a bowling pin and asked the same question they’d answer bowling. I think they know what it is and they think it’s called a pin.

I will assume that we means jugglers here. Are you suggesting that jugglers somehow get together and decide over what word “we” should use when we talk about (the object formerly known as) clubs? This is not a possible scenario, I think? And I still do not understand what the problem is? Seems as if David thinks the audience generally thinks the clubs are bowling pins, but Thomas seems to think they know the difference, but are unaware of what word to use when talking about them. David likes to inform them of the difference, both in concept and in word to represent what they are, which I think is perfectly fine. Can you explain your problem further Thomas, sorry that I do not follow.
I’ve had people simply not know what to call clubs. They just point and say “can you juggle those things?”.

That 10 second bit in my show serves to:
A. Educate the audience in juggling terminology.
B. Demonstrates their lightness.
C. A small moment of levity before a 6 minute juggling routine with no talking or jokes.
D. Establishes that I may not make it through without a mistake, and that a mere drop isn’t a huge failure (anything less than a club bouncing off stage is great, I guess?).
E. Means that later, when I get out the juggling knives, there is a bigger gap between the “danger” of juggling knives and the total non-danger of juggling clubs.
I think this type of juggling terminology education is very important to include in one’s act.

forum.content: After that i think we can relax and not sacred title. You write a poem why not being a poet ? Why the title of being is that scary ? It's not being megalomane.

posts.content:
So, when exactly can you define yourself as being whatever you pretend to be?
Is it the skills that grant you the title of "juggler"?
Is it your devotion?
Is it the years you´ve been doing it?
Is it that you make a living out of it?
After that i think we can relax and not sacred title. You write a poem why not being a poet ? Why the title of being is that scary ? It's not being megalomane.

I believe every juggler passes through some sort or "revelation". There is a particular moment where you're just moving your props and you sudenly realize you're a juggler or to me at least it happened that way.

There is no established definition of juggling, but we do have established, recognized forms of juggling. For an example Ignatov is a juggler, what he performs is juggling, even if we cannot (yet) precisely determine why that is the case. One can identify as a juggler by relating one's own activity to already recognised juggling, and in this way place one's own activity in the category of juggling.

I can relate to Ignatov, but I guess I mostly do "silly" things with the objects. I've tryed doing street performances with just one object. sometimes putting on tricks way more difficult than tossing 5 balls into the air, and people don't recognize it as juggling. Often I have to swallow comments such as "That was cute, but can you juggle?",or "Can you "do it" with 3 "pins"?"(juggling somehow resembles bowling...)
They sure have the ability to make me wonder if I'm a juggler, or I'm just stupid.
Rhythmic gymnasts are the perfect example of this - their discipline involves object manipulation at a higher level than many jugglers ever achieve. But how many of them would say "I'm a juggler"?
